product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Gaming 3 - (2022) - Essential Gaming Laptop Computer - 15.6" FHD - 120Hz - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 8GB DDR5 RAM - 256GB NVMe Storage - Windows 11 Home
text: The model I received comes with a Ryzen 5 6600U, RTX 3050 4GB, 8GB of DDR5-4800 (I added another 8 gigs before doing much else so bear that in mind for performance reviews), and a 256 gig internal storage drive (I use an external 1TB SSD for games).Not a bad laptop overall. Had some issues but some were caused by Windows, not the laptop itself.If you're upgrading the RAM or storage, be extra sure to make sure Windows doesn't have any updates waiting. Windows 11 made the great decision to no longer tell users if their shutting down of a PC would also be applying updates. So unplugging the battery and adding more RAM unknowingly mid-update despite having shut down the laptop bricked my operating system and I had to reinstall. Downside is that you need ethernet upon a reinstall so you can download wifi drivers. Upside is it gets rid of the bloatware Lenovo tries preinstalling with the laptop.The inside is pretty simple, RAM is covered by a small metal tray with thermal pads on it for heat dissipation. A free M.2 storage slot is right in the open, ready for you to add storage as needed (you will need it). Thermals seem pretty solid, fans ramp up in gaming (I barely hear them over my headset which I don't run very loud and is an open-back headset, meaning I can hear noises outside of the headset fairly well) but rarely get too extreme.For gaming, it's a mixed bag. Needless to say, ray tracing will not be something you'll use on this laptop for playable frame rates. I doubt even 30 fps is achievable without dropping to 720p or less. Rainbow Six Siege was able to handle 1080p 120 fps consistently with mixed graphics settings (90 fov, ultra LOD, Medium textures and Shadows, most else set to low) with or without DLSS enabled. Though I did experience a bug where the render scaling option said I was running at ~850p even with the render scaling set to 100... an oddity to be sure. Halo Reach struggled to achieve similar results on Forge World, with bad tearing when the fps cap was set to 120. I lowered it to 60 and all was well, though drops may not be out of the question in high-intensity situations like custom games or campaign. Minecraft Java ran mostly above 60 fps on a modded server without Optifine or any other performance enhancers. Even in a particularly-taxing area it was mostly fine when the render distance was turned down. I'm sure with the use of Optifine or Sodium it'd be a very solid gaming experience.Windows 11 is a bit of a chore. Upon first installing Steam, I realized that my default Documents folder pinned to my Quick Access in the File Explorer was labeled under OneDrive. I never gave OneDrive permission to backup anything on my PC, as the measley 5 GB it gives you isn't enough for anything I would use a computer for. But it forces a backup, and deleting from the OneDrive cloud deletes it from your PC as well for... some insane reason. So be wary if you use Windows 11, make sure you remove the tabs from the Quick Access bar in File Explorer and replace them with the actual local file locations (Documents, Pictures, Music, etc).The keyboard is... weird. I've used mechanical and membrane alike in plenty of scenarios, but this one just feels weird compared to either. It's not unusable by any means but it takes getting used to. The trackpad is fine, I prefer having mouse buttons with my trackpad but it's not unusable even without them.The speakers are tinny. For 2W speakers it's not bad but it's not going to have the amazing sound quality the description would lead you to believe. Would suggest using headphones.The I/O is alright. Type-C with full DisplayPort functionality is nice to have, HDMI 2.0 is plenty for what this laptop is capable of, and the back-facing Ethernet and charging ports are quite handy in most situations. I've always been a fan of Lenovo's chargers as well, for some reason the reversible square shape just feels right. My only complaint would be a lack of USB ports, and the lack of SD/MicroSD. I know the latter is getting up there in age which makes it more a personal preference, but the former can make it difficult to use with numerous external devices (keyboard, mouse, storage, controllers, etc) since you are limited to 3 max only if you have type-C connectivity, otherwise you get two ports for peripherals and nothing more. An extra USB 2 port would have been nice to have.Overall it's a solid deal. Boot times are fast, gaming feels alright, the wifi signal is solid (though I did notice some lag while using a bluetooth Xbox Series controller with wifi, need to test and see if the lag is still present while using ethernet) and the laptop is easy to modify for basics like RAM and storage for the most part. A solid system from Lenovo.*Update 2/11/2023 - Found out that this laptop actually does support VRR via AMD Freesync. However, this is not listed anywhere the laptop can be found. I had to install AMD's graphics software in order to enable it, despite the laptop having an Nvidia GPU inside. This helped immensely with stuttery FPS in various games, though issues with Nvidia control panel's FPS limits caused other issues unrelated with the laptop itself.
title: Decent value gaming laptop

text:
The media could not be loaded.
                
            
                
            
            
        
    
    








  
  
     Upside:- Appearance is nice and simple with a bit of flair add-on with the back exhaust.- CPU is quite snappy and GPU is a treat to throw at some AAA games that is recent (2023) and almost run flawless in AAA games that is a few years old (COD: Cold War Zombies).- I/O Ports are just enough for the average person to use.- 120hz display is quick and responsive!- Upgrading the Laptop limited hardware is a bit tricky but with a bit of time it's really easy to do so.Neutral:- Screen brightness/Keyboard/Speakers are just "Meh." It will get you by just enough to be acceptable. Small adjustments is needed right out of the box.- 256GB SSD/8GB RAM isn't suitable for modern games at all but it come with the cost of the laptop.- 720p Camera is just there to be used for a quick call video. And the Mic too.Downsides:- Battery life isn't great. Expect to get about 3-4 hours of basic use in "Balanced" mode and 4-5 hours in "Quite" mode if the screen brightness is 75%/Bluetooth is off and speakers is at 50% (Or headphones plugged in to bypass it). Expect the battery drain faster if you're playing a somewhat demanding game.- The fans can get LOUD when playing a demanding game!Overall:For $650, you can't go wrong with that deal (At that time). I wanted a laptop to kind of replaced my 8 year old desktop and my hand-me-down laptop that was 12 years old before I gave it to a friend of mine that really needed a PC for basic tasks. I had around a grand from my check and I just was looking to see if any deals at the time. And then this laptop came up and I said "Why not? It looks decent enough to have andto upgrade." And here we are. I even added 32GB DDR5/2TB Storage upgrade ASAP that cost me nearly $300 alone, putting the cost close to the entire check I have, and do I regret it? Nah. It's exactly what I wanted. There are some flaws with this laptop but at the price that I paid for it's outweigh the cons, but I do recommend getting the ideapad series on a sale because it's a hell of a deal if you are planning to keep the laptop for years on end like me. It's been about 3 months and so far I am loving my new laptop!But sadly the model I have currently (3050, R5-6600H) is getting replace by the newer and more expensive model that have a 4050, R7-7735HS which IS a better laptop via hardware but it's going to be a while for a good sale to happen for the 4050 version. Again, if you're really looking to get a decent modern gaming laptop look at this laptop at least before it's truly gone.

product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Gaming 3 - (2022) - Essential Gaming Laptop Computer - 15.6" FHD - 120Hz - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 8GB DDR5 RAM - 256GB NVMe Storage - Windows 11 Home
text: Why does the 3.5mm jack on a laptop produce better better clarity, soundstage, and imaging than my dedicated hifi dac did... I just wanted to point out something nobody else is talking about.Gaming - Better than expectedTemps - GoodFans - Mid-volume. Almost all laptops you'll have to deal with small, shrill fans. This is no exception, but I'd rate them slightly above average from my samples. A cooling pad with larger, quieter fans caused the laptop fans to go down way low. Responds well to cooling pad, as most laptops do.Keyboard - Top-notch. Very satisfying to type on. Clickety clickety click.Touchpad - Once you get used to the fact that your single-taps can't be feather-light, I think everything else about it is good. However, I can say that.. Sometimes I'll single tap and it won't do anything. But I have skinny fingers. And it's cold?Screen Brightness - It's medium, it's not very bright like people say. Also I've tried several of the power saving tweaks, mine never changed, maybe yours will.I'll come back as I continue to use this. Been a week.Standout - Surprisingly good quality from the 3.5mm jack. Perhaps audiophile quality, I will keep tweaking stuff and see how good I can get it to sound. But so far, very clear. Soundstage out of the gate seemed more deep than wide. May need a little boost around the 500hz area for my liking. String guitars sounded phenomenally realistic. Center image for me was very good. Using an old Sherwood Newcastle 963t amp, sony sscs5 stereo speakers with a very slightly included yamaha sub. I don't like overpowering bass. I was hearing far more detail from this soundcard than my Xonar DG "hifi" 192khz desktop card. Also better than both my Sherwood and Onkyo receiver's DACs. This is a big thing for me because along with portability I wanted to make sure I didn't lose my hifi. I was prepared to go DAC-hopping after selling my desktop for this laptop. Because why would a gaming laptop have ideal sound for hifi music?Well, so far it's beating my other dedicated hifi dac only on its 3.5 so, I might just keep it like this lol. I will try other DACS eventually and see if there's anything going on there. But this onboard sound is more clear than my dedicated DAC. I will see if I can get instruments to sound like real instruments. Cello didn't quite hit that buttery sound that I like, that's why I may boost the 500hz or so. But the highs sounded refined, very pinpoint accurate and tickly. Bongos sounded very poppy and in-room. High strings like banjo and guitar sound spot on. Mid-bass clarity was awesome, and actually now had location. My old DAC didn't really place some of those lower sounding instruments at all.The purpose of this review was to give you another bonus that you may not have considered. Read other reviews for more on gaming and other features but for audio I am highly enjoying it. I think it definitely upped my hifi listening. Which I was not expecting at all. Awesome laptop on all points for me so far. Ask around, maybe I just got a magic pairing of equipment but I think it's very good for what it is.
title: Umm anyone gonna point out the audio quality?

product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Gaming 3 - (2022) - Essential Gaming Laptop Computer - 15.6" FHD - 120Hz - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 8GB DDR5 RAM - 256GB NVMe Storage - Windows 11 Home
text: I've had this Lenovo ideapad gaming 3 Ryzen 5 6600h rtx 3050 version with 8gb ddr5 ram & 256gb ssd for about a month now and so far the performance has been spectacular. There are a couple irritations rather then cons ill get into shortly. I was hesitant not knowing if this setup would run the games I play at the highest resolutions and frame rate this PC offers.This laptop has been flawless at running call of duty MW 2(2009), COD black Ops and GTA 5 on the highest settings with out any hiccups, choppy video, freezing etc. For me it has been lightning fast and silky smooth. Yes there are higher frame rates out there but the costs are astronomic for what little upgrades you get.I love the fact I haven't found any bloatware in this PC. Although not recommended by Lenovo it does allow overclocking. It stays cool even with heavy gameplay for hours on end. The fans work great at dispersing heat and are not so loud you get distracted while gaming. When just casually running browsers or streaming the fans never kick on it just stays cool enough to not need them.I've read users think its not sturdy enough? I think its very sturdy. The keyboard doesn't flex while pushing keys and its quite hefty. The screen doesn't feel wobbly or weak. Its not made of aluminum like an Asus tuf f15 but it does the job well.Other users say the brightness and colors are dim but that has not been the case for me. Its not 4k but I had to turn the brightness down. The colors are great for me. If you are a professional photo editor or video editor just get an external monitor. You shouldn't be editing professional work on a 15.6" screen anyway haha its a gaming laptop not a photo/video workstation.  You'll need more power to render huge files.The only cons/ irritations-256gb ssd is just an outdated size for storage. GTA 5 alone is 142gb. Yes it can be upgraded but at least a 512gb should be standard. Crucial says it will support 2tb but I have not personally added that size. I will definitely be upgrading to at least 1tb.8gb ram has worked flawlessly with the aforementioned games I have installed. But it would have been nice to see a standard 16gb (2×8gb ddr5) cards installed. I will be upgrading to 32gb ddr5 2x16gb cards just because. The price jump for 16gb factory is crazy! Upgrading to 16gb costs like 40 bucks verses a $200 price jump for 16gb pre installed.So far I have not found any other cons to this system. I love it and am very happy with its performance and price. I don't think you'll find a better laptop at this price for gaming.Note I do have lightroom installed and it runs flawless. But its just for casual photo editing.I couldn't be happier. A+ purchase.
title: Unbeatable performance at $649
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2023

product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Gaming 3 - (2022) - Essential Gaming Laptop Computer - 15.6" FHD - 120Hz - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 8GB DDR5 RAM - 256GB NVMe Storage - Windows 11 Home
text: Ok to make this quick and sweet and since I'm not very good at making reviews I'll start with the good and then end with the issues at least I've experienced with mine in the past few days I've had it and been using it.The laptop is actually pretty good at playing about anything I throw at it even if it is over the specs like resident evil village at absolute maximum settings with ray tracing on with the laptop only on balanced mode. I still got about 30-50 frames even with the settings at max. It also can handle the new dead space remake quite well. the laptop is quite responsive as well and never really got too hot even when being stressed I rarely heard the fans kick up like my more expensive MSI ge66 raider. Now for the issues I've had with mine, when I first got mine I had a issue where playing videos weather it was in Microsoft edge/Chrome on YouTube or local videos it would cause the whole display to glitch in a glitchy pattern, flash to black like windows had crashed and then reopened everything, lock up the video playback at one frame with audio still playing then suddenly zoom the video to where it should be, or flicker between two frames with audio and time still going then suddenly zoom forward to where the video should be at. I did reinstall the Nvidia and AMD drivers but it still persisted which is where the second issue happened even though I think this was more to do with windows but the visual c++ 2015 - 2022 redistributable wouldn't install because I think there was a issue with visual c++ 2015 - 2019 redistributable not wanting to update or even letting me uninstall it like it didn't exist even though it was there. To fix that I had to reinstall windows 11 using windows reset with the option to keep my personal files selected where my 3rd issue came up but fixed itself I guess after a full system shutdown for hours. After the reset the Lenovo ACPI disappeared and so did the power modes and other parts of the Lenovo Vantage side bar options so I couldn't use quick charge or conservation mode even after manually installing the Lenovo ACPI it didn't come back or show in device manager only seeing the Microsoft ACPI. I even tried reinstalling Lenovo vantage and it's services but that didn't work. To fix that I uninstalled the Microsoft ACPI then installed the Lenovo ACPI then shut down my laptop for like 5-6 hours. After all that even though it still shows Microsoft ACPI in device manager the Lenovo vantage settings came back. The final issue which goes back to the video playback issue. I think I found the solution along with reinstalling the drivers you have to disable "Use Hardware Acceleration When Available" setting in chrome seems to have fixed that issue from what I know of as of making this review. But there's another issue from that which happened at least once when I turned that setting back on and watched a video as soon as I started up the video the feedback froze and then suddenly the whole display went completely black even the backlight and then my system suddenly restarted. In event viewer it said it was from Kernel-Power with event ID:41. Not exactly sure what to make of that but it appeared in the event viewer as a critical error at the same time the system crashed and restarted from the video.So in summery this laptop is great for everyday gaming if you're not expecting extreme power. It will get you by with the current specs if you want a budget entry level gaming laptop but there might be issues in some areas unless I got a little faulty system. I'm thinking the issues I've had with video playback are drivers causing problems I'll keep a eye on it and see if more problems come up while using it more.
title: Pretty powerful and decent at your basic every day gaming needs but may have a few issues.

product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Gaming 3 - (2022) - Essential Gaming Laptop Computer - 15.6" FHD - 120Hz - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 8GB DDR5 RAM - 256GB NVMe Storage - Windows 11 Home
text: When I first got this laptop, it had everything I needed. Able to run games medium to high graphics and perfect as a university student along with multitasking. Normally I would clean the inside and outside of the laptop once every month since it doesn't get dusty that often and the laptop runs cool even after 7 months, with the highest temps being 73'C for both the CPU and GPU.Now, the problem is the black screen of death. I checked for everything; made sure the ram was seated properly, disconnected the CMOS battery to reset the BIOS settings (even though I didn't update it), checked to see if it was my external monitor or HDMI cable (since I use an external monitor), I always shutdown my computer before either going to sleep or going on the road, tried running it without the battery and NOTHING. The laptop is still working fine, the fans spin and the keyboard still lights up but only the screen died. I followed every possible known solution on the net that fixes it but unfortunately none have worked for me and it seems that my entire screen has just stopped working abruptly (it was working perfectly fine the other night with no flickers).I would've rate 5 stars but to see this happen to a very respectable and reliable laptop and it hasn't even been a year or two since I got it, is sadly disappointing.

product_name: Lenovo IdeaPad Flex 5-2023 - Touchscreen 2-in-1 Laptop - Windows 11 Home - 14" FHD Display - 16GB Memory - 512GB Storage - AMD Ryzen 5 5500U - Abyss Blue
text: Purchased the Ideapad Flex 5 16" R7-512GB laptop version while it was on sale on Prime Day for $699. So far I am overall happy with this unit. The screen quality is very good for a lower to mid budget laptop and colors are vibrant enough. Touchscreen works great as well. I like the idea of the flexibility of changing between laptop mode and tablet mode. The 16" screen size in tablet mode is great for watching movies and other random entertaining things, but if your goal is to use it for note taking or similar, it is a little on the larger side and would recommend the 14" instead.  My main purpose is to use it for travels and remote work via remote desktop, so the additional real estate on the screen was important for me for my engineering work (CAD and programming).Since I also have a need for multiple monitors when stationary, I went ahead and also purchased a cheap off-brand USB-C docking station from Falwedi on Amazon. I was able to expand to at least 2 additional monitors, resulting in a triple monitor setup, one 24" Dell 1080 and another 27" Dell 2K. I did however get some issues where the external monitors would blank for a second or two occasionally, but not yet sure if this was due to the current drivers on the Ideapad or the off-brand docking station. Something I will need to investigate further at a later time.Sound quality from the speakers is just ok. There is no base, which I wouldn't expect from a lower budget laptop anyways. The camera worked decently and clear, which is sufficient for most video conferences anyways.The fingerprint reader works flawlessly and makes login into Windows and other biometric supporting apps super easy.I am however surprised on how heavy this unit is for being a new modern 16" model. Reminds me of my 10+ year old Toshiba brick. Another drawback is that the pen or stylus was not included with it and is sold separately.There is no ethernet port and for those that want to utilize wired connections, will need to purchase an additional dongle.

text: For the last 10 months, I have had nothing but problems from my ThinkPad and Lenovo's customer service. The trouble began with a failure to charge/ boot (a common occurrence according to online reviews). I sent the unit with a 1TB SSD that was upgraded by this Amazon seller to The Depot in Houston. To my dismay, it was returned to me with a new motherboard and no SSD or harddrive. I returned it to The Depot and they returned it with the standard 256GB SSD. Lenovo refuses to return or replace the 1TB SSD because they claim it is not an original part and it is not covered under the warranty. I contacted the Amazon seller but they have not responded.Upon receiving unit the second time from the Depot the unit was still unusable because the operating system was removed. Lenovo offered to send a replacement unit with the standard specifications (not with a 1TB SSD or upgraded RAM). However, I declined because I did not want to have a standard model after having paid for an upgraded model. product_name: HP 2022 Stream 14" HD BrightView Laptop, Intel Celeron N4120, 4GB RAM, 64GB SSD, Intel HD Graphics, 720p Webcam, 1 Year Office 365, Gold, Win 11, 32GB Snowbell USB Card
text: Comes with Windows 11 and S-mode, but seller provides clear instructions on how to get out of S-mode. Other than the intrusive drawbacks of Windows 11, the computer itself is a nice color and a value for the money.  The seller neglected to include the "Snowbell" card, which is a flat, credit-card size 32gb USB drive.  But when I contacted the seller about it, he quickly sent one, no questions asked. If all you want to do is email, web surfing, and some light office work, this computer is more than sufficient.  It  needs more storage, but you can buy an inexpensive USB backup drive for that.

It’s not backlit, but that is in the description, so I wasn’t expecting it to be. But I don’t have an issue seeing the letters on the keyboard. Overall, I am very happy with this purchase so far!

product_name: HP 2022 15.6" HD BrightView Laptop, Intel Pentium Silver N5030 Processor, 8GB RAM, 256GB PCIe SSD, Intel HD Graphics 605, 720p HD Webcam, Stereo Speakers, Silver, Windows 11, 32GB USB Card
text: I bought this laptop as a replacement for my wife's previous one. Fortunately, I have a fair amount of computer experience. Otherwise, I would never have been able to bypass all of the hurdles that Microsoft has built into their system. No -- I DO NOT want a Microsoft account nor do I want to give them free passage to my data. Secondly, there are many programs and apps that are not beholden to Microsoft. Finding a way around their restrictions was a nightmare. If I had not had another computer, I don't think that I could have been successful in getting her machine going. Once I got everything in place, we have no complaints. The speed of the laptop is awesome. One suggestion: unless you go into the startup menu and deactivate the McAfee app, you will receive MANY alerts that tries to get you to purchase their software, and, these pop-ups are all but impossible to work around. Otherwise, Great Value for the Price!
title: Works Great Once you Figure how to Bypass all the Microsoft Garbage
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2023

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2021

product_name: HP Pavilion 15.6" FHD Laptop, AMD Ryzen 5 5500U (Beats i7-11370H), Thin & Portable, Micro-Edge & Anti-Glare Screen, Long Battery Life, Windows 11 (16GB RAM | 1TB PCIe SSD)
text: Sending this Chromebook back. Tried to set up and use as a productive travel laptop and the unit would get extremely hot to the touch AND no way if you USE the thing does the battery last close to "10 hours". Had registered it with HP and tried to get support. Everything was "virtual" with all the wrong questions, no answers and no simple way to contact a human. There are no air vents on the bottom, side or top so temperatures build up quickly and very high. I am well versed in lithium batteries and solid state electronics from my career as well as hobbies and HEAT is a killer of batteries and electronics.At the HP site in my futile quest for HUMAN tech support, after I was asked to put in the model and serial numbers, a message came back saying 'this model was no longer supported by HP'??? I thought it was the latest and greatest from HP? I'm a computer guy clear back to the Timex Sinclair, Texas Instruments and Commodore days and my job had me working DOS, Unix and Windows environments so I'm no novice. This unit is not designed for any kind of moderate use and I cannot believe batteries and electronics getting that hot have much of a lifespan so after failing to contact anyone knowledgeable at HP AND finding out this model is NOT supported by them any longer, I decided to send it back.
title: Gets very hot under normal use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021

I am well versed in lithium batteries and solid state electronics from my career as well as hobbies and HEAT is a killer of batteries and electronics.At the HP site in my futile quest for HUMAN tech support, after I was asked to put in the model and serial numbers, a message came back saying 'this model was no longer supported by HP'??? I thought it was the latest and greatest from HP? I'm a computer guy clear back to the Timex Sinclair, Texas Instruments and Commodore days and my job had me working DOS, Unix and Windows environments so I'm no novice. This unit is not designed for any kind of moderate use and I cannot believe batteries and electronics getting that hot have much of a lifespan so after failing to contact anyone knowledgeable at HP AND finding out this model is NOT supported by them any longer, I decided to send it back.
title: Gets very hot under normal use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021

text: HP no cubre un equipo actualizado con garantía, así que si es un riesgo, buen precio, la caja del equipo si se ve que fue abierta, en mi caso trajo 1 TB con 32 GB de RAM, funciona muy bien y muy rápida, la tarjeta Nvidia excelente desempeño, viene con Windows 11 Home, no es Single Lenguage, por lo que pude cambiar al Español sin ningún problema, el teclado en Ingles no es problema para mi, es retroiluminado, solo en tono blanco. title: Buena laptop Actualizada
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2023

product_name: HP Spectre X360 2-in-1 Touchscreen Laptop, 16" 3K+ Touchscreen, Intel Core i7-12700H Evo, 16GB RAM, 512GB SSD, Webcam, Wi-Fi 6, Backlit KB, FP Reader, MPP2.0 Tilt Pen Included, Win11 Home
text: I have sensory issues with sound and flashing lights. I have not been able to use my computer for 7 years because of it. I got my HP Spectre x360 and it is amazing. I cried when I got it and it felt like home. It's quiet. Quiet!!!!! I never hear the fan. I can do my computer art on it. I have no problems with photoshop and painter. I have 3d Blender on it but haven't used it yet. I shouldn't have a problem with it rendering on Eevee with it.I have used it in multiple rooms with different lighting.I love the touch screen. I can use the hp tilt pen on the screen but there is no pressure nor tilt to it. After researching I found HP has been blaming windows for 4 plus years and not fixed their drivers for the pen. So the pen gets 1 star. I was so excited to use the angle and pressure brushes with it and it works just as well as my finger. In photoshop and painter, the tilt pen will leave random dots flying around the art work. If pressing too light it will not draw or will skip. I have to hold screen in place with one arm and draw with the other to get enough pressure for the pen. I connected my old Wacom intuos tablet to it and it works like a dream with it. Image is a quick test with the same brushes used top and bottom- HP Tilt Pen on the laptop screen and Wacom Intuos pen on the wacom tablet.It plays music beautifully. Have watched some movies, played a few low quality games.I am still in the puttering stage getting use to using my laptop and I am so glad I bought it.Notes. When folded so screen is facing you and keyboard is behind. Make sure back vent gets air flow. Don't charge laptop in the case it comes with. Plugging in charger may turn it on and fan needs air. I charge it once or twice a day. But I don't like my electronics to go below 40-50%I love laptop!
title: I love my laptop!!!! I don't like the HP tilt pen.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2023

It started with the sound crackling and eventually not working, and it progressed to the keyboard and TouchPad completely ceasing to work. Nothing works.Anyways, now I'm stuck with what is pretty much a big ol' pricey tablet.

text: I’ve had this laptop for about 3 months now. I game on it pretty regularly. Always get high frame rates on high settings. So no complaint there. Yes it gets really hot while gaming around 82 degrees Celsius for the gpu. What I like about it is it pretty much stops using cpu and only uses the gpu while gaming. product_name: Alienware X17 R2 VR Ready Gaming Laptop - 17.3-inch FHD 360Hz 1ms Display, Core i7-12700H, 16GB RAM, 1TB SSD, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070Ti 8GB GDDR6, Bluetooth, Wi-Fi 6, USB-C, Windows 11 Home - White
text: *update this has been a huge headache, the monitor flickers and often forces the pc into sleep mode. Dell has sent a tech 3 times to replace damn near everything and the issue remains. I’m now being told to mail the system back so they can try to figure it out. I’ve had the machine 3 weeks and really can’t use it without this issue poking its head out so often it’s unusable. I really wish they’d just send me a replacement machine at this point it’s clearly faulty even after motherboard replaced, monitor replaced, fans and heat sink replaced, and have reset the system with clean install. C’mon Dell just own the issue of a faulty machine at this point and do right by the customer*First and foremost this thing is powerful. Beautiful display quality, and the design looks slick. That being said its not perfect but a machine this powerful you will expect some setbacks. She gets hot, so get a laptop pad that allows air to flow under more is a must, ones with fans will work a touch better. Just make sure its vented and not a flat surface, it makes a difference. The speakers do suck but who games with laptop speakers anyway?One thing to note is the white glove service you get from dell. My machine had a heating issue due to faulty cooling parts. Dell was absolutely helpful and sending a tech to my home to repair it onsite. You dont get that service many places at all. For that alone its a 5 star machine. 10/10 would recommend this if its in your budget and you need the power.
title: What a beast but I have a flawed machine*update*

product_name: Alienware X17 R2 VR Ready Gaming Laptop - 17.3-inch FHD 360Hz 1ms Display, Core i7-12700H, 16GB RAM, 1TB SSD, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070Ti 8GB GDDR6, Bluetooth, Wi-Fi 6, USB-C, Windows 11 Home - White
text: Extremely disappointed in Dell for the quality of this machine. The computer is defective and dangerous.Last week I purchased the computer brand new and it arrived in sealed box in “perfect” condition. Booted up with no issues and I proceeded to update with necessary drivers and software. A few hours later I go to turn off the computer and I pick up the power adapter and burn myself. Could not pick the adapter for about a half hour as it was much too hot to touch. Thought this was strange.The next day I boot up the computer again to see what happens to the power adapter. I do some light gaming for a few hours (all in-game graphics settings were set as default and profile of the graphics card was set to balanced with no over clocking). I finish and turn off the computer and again the power adapter is way too hot to touch. I then go to move the computer and touch the area above the function keys and subsequently burn myself again. What is going on…The third day is testing day. Armed with a digital infrared thermometer, I now have the tools to see how hot things are getting. Before booting up I scan the surface of the power adapter and area around the keyboard. All check out fine around room temperature ~72 degrees. I then boot up and repeat the same process as the previous day and after an hour I test. The surface of the power adapter (located unobstructed on the floor, no clutter around it) checks in at 150 degrees, and the backside on the floor checks in even hotter. Next I test around the surface of the computer (the entire unit including the fans and vents are unobstructed with the closet obstruction several feet away). The area above the function keys checks in over 140 degrees. Areas on the sides and corners above the fans check in around 120-130 degrees. The keyboard itself is over 110. Not good.The next day things take a drastic turn. After the tests of the previous day I shutdown the computer but this time I left the power adapter plugged into the wall and plugged into the computer overnight (previously I had been disconnecting these). I attempt to turn on the computer but it does not turn on. I then touch the keyboard and surface and am surprised as it is very warm, and the power adapter is also very warm. Further testing reveals the power adapter to be over 100 degrees and the area above the keyboard to be over 120 degrees. So now not only does the computer not boot, but it is also heating up to unacceptable levels when it is shutdown and plugged in. Further, after unplugging the power adapter to the shutdown computer and waiting 30 minutes, the unit still remains hot with surfaces over 120 degrees in some places.After evaluating all of the evidence (the two burns on my hands, the temperature readings, the computer settings, and the failure to boot) my verdict is that this machine is defective and dangerous. Burning oneself is bad enough, but this unit has the potential to cause far more damage. I do not feel comfortable keeping this machine inside my house and potentially putting the lives of my family at risk as I have no doubt that this computer is a dangerous fire hazard.I paid thousands of dollars for this computer and am extremely disappointed and frustrated that Dell would produce such a poor quality and dangerous product. I will be attempting to return/exchange this unit and luckily I am covered under the return grace period and manufacturers warranty. I also purchased the extended warranty as well and would recommend this to anyone making a purchase like this. Buyer Beware.
title: Defective and Dangerous
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2022

product_name: UMIDIGI Cell Phone G1, Android12 Unlocked Cell Phone, Dual Sim 4G LTE Mobile Phone, 3+32GB 256G Expandable, 6.52" HD+, 5150mAh, GSM Unlocked
text: This is an inexpensive Android phone and assessing it should reflect that fact. If you take that perspective then this phone merits the four stars I'm giving it here. It is not nor does its makers claim it to be a premium product, but those who want premium performance should cough up the premium price for it. For the hundred bucks you do pay for this phone you get your money's worth, and a bit more. It's reliable, sturdy, and has the essentials you should expect for calls, on-line access, texting, and running most apps. The camera is not great and while I'm not much of a gamer, I don't expect that it would run the latest games with great efficiency. But this is a device I'd get for someone who wants basic Android functionality and is not interested in paying for all the bells and whistles of high-end brands. It's fine for less tech-centric people, and if you have a kid who wants a phone that handles the fastest games and demanding video, give him or her the hundred bucks that this one costs and tell them to go get an after-school job or solicit odd jobs for neighbors to raise the extra five, six, nine hundred or more dollars to get it. This one, however, is more than adequate for the basics.
title: You Get What You Pay For and That's OK
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2023

text: The picture is nice.  Sound is good too.  The TV doesn’t like it when it gets turned off while in an app.  It also doesn’t like it if you try to go to the Home Screen by using the home button while in an app.  It prefers that you use the back button. Using the back button takes many seconds longer for every step you back up from.  If you turn the power off or press the home button the TV will freeze.  By this I mean that you can scroll up and down on the Home Screen but when you try to select an app or any other option, the screen will freeze. The remedy is to unplug the tv and plug it in again. Besides that, I also have the Hisense sound bar.  The odd thing is that there is no volume indicator on the screen when using the sound bar.  The volume indicator shows on the screen only when you’re using the tv speakers and not the connected sound bar.  So you don’t have an idea of how loud it is when using the sound bar other than what you hear. The price is right though. If you’re going to have these issues, better on this than a higher priced tv.

product_name: Black Widow
text: Ten minutes in I was *certain* I must have missed some major prior movies, because there were all these references & characters that I had no idea about, but yet were clearly supposed to mean something to me (lots of ominous pauses & slow-motion, as if I'm supposed to gasp and say "oh no!  not him again!").  Maybe if you're well-versed in the comics, this all makes sense?Turns out I hadn't missed any of the previous movies, it's just this movie starts out very rough.  The plot itself is easy to follow, though, so it wasn't too hard to just go with it, and by the end it comes together reasonably well.  I'm still confused about why I was clearly supposed to know a bunch of backstory that hasn't been covered in any prior MCU movies, but, oh well…As for what it is… it's enjoyable.  It felt kind of like a big episode of Agents of Shield.  It's more "human" in some respects than most of the other MCU movies, and there's even some self-deprecating, self-aware humour in places to that affect.  Agent Romanoff is only human, after all.It's hard to detail some of my favourite aspects without spoilers… suffice to say that one of the new characters, tied to Black Widow, was a surprising hit for me.  Very well played, with great dialog that really embodied the tone of the movie.Some part of it didn't do it for me, though.  I can't put my finger on it.  Maybe it's just that after dozens of MCU movies it's feeling a bit samey?  I dunno.  It's an above-average MCU movie, but there's no risk of it displacing my top favourites.

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: I will start this review off by saying these are not my best sounding headphones.  My Beyerdynamic Aventho and Audeze Penrose sound better in almost every way.  In fact, my cursed Drop Panda that no longer even turn on might even sound better and I do not like how they sound wired because I remember how good they sounded wireless when tuned to my hearing preferences.  But that's not really why I love these headphones so much.To be fair, they don't sound bad at all.  But I bought them for a completely different reason than any of the aforementioned headphones.  I bought these for their 2.4Ghz wireless feature as the words "lossless" and "low-latency" are really what sold this for me.  I wanted a pair of headphones for monitoring and general studio use to replace my missing Sennheiser HD280.  But I liked the idea of being able to play my keyboard and digital piano without being tied down by wires or monitoring my microphones for work calls without having wires sprawled all over my desk.  In fact, the idea of being able to just listen to music wirelessly but without the latency and hassle of bluetooth was calling me.The biggest disadvantage to these headphones in my mind is not how they sound - as I said before, these aren't my best sounding headphones.  No, the worst feature is the hiss you get when you use them over 2.4GHz.  You can mediate this a bit by turning down the volume on the headphones themselves and raising it at the source, but these aren't the loudest/easiest to drive headphones, so you could find yourself nearly maxing out volume depending on the device and audio program/app you're listening to.  In most cases, I've just learned to live with the hiss because not having the wire is more important in the situation where I choose to use this headphone over 2.4Ghz.  (btw, the Avantree Audiplex 2403 is an option for enjoying wireless 2.4Ghz audio with much less hiss but also with the slight hassle of an additional dongle and cable involved - I did a review of that as well; it's pretty great for what it is).  When you want freedom from wires, having "lossless" and "low-latency" wireless freedom is just great.  2.4Ghz is so much better than even AptX LL.My second reason for loving these headphones is how comfortable they are for my small head.  Because I have very short hair and a relatively small lady-head, most headphones don't fit me well even at their smallest headband setting.  I usually have to go with on-ear options like the aforementioned Aventho or my beloved Marshall Mid ANC because they fit me.  But over-ear is still more comfortable than on-ear and these headphones with their Alcantara earcups fit me better and are more comfortable for me than any other pair over over-ear headphones I currently own.  So I reach for these even though my Penrose sounds better and is also wireless via 2.4Ghz dongle. I reach for it over my Bluetooth headhones and wired/wirelss earphones.And that brings me to the next thing I love about these headphones.  Because Aiaiai makes so many pieces for these headphones, they can kinda be whatever you want them to be.  I picked up the USB-C cable (which I had to import from Europe at a stupid price, sigh), and the straight 3.5mm cable (direct from Aiaiai).  When I'm in a situation where I don't need the wireless freedom, I can plug the headphones into one of my Android devices via the USB-C cable, or I can even plug in the 3.5mm cable into one of my USB DACs or my Sony DAP.  I love the flexibility this system offers me and I love the idea that if there's an upgrade to the wireless system, I can swap out the headband and transmitter someday (hopefully for one with less hiss).  If the earcups wear out, I can replace them.  And if the company comes out with improved drivers, I can upgrade that as well.  I would buy these headphones again in a heartbeat if something happened to them.BTW - I haven't seen any reviews anywhere comparing these to the new Rode NTH-100.  My husband, who is a drummer and budding DJ, just picked up a pair for his own monitoring purposes.  They are very similar in sound and if you have small ears, similar in comfort.  I find that my ears are just large enough that I feel the earcups on the Rode (probably again because of the position of the cups on my small head) and while that isn't annoying, I do know from reading reviews that this annoys some people.  There is an audible difference in the midrange (~300-400hz) between the two as the Rode has a slight bump in almost the exact place where the TMA-2 has a slight dip and there is more presence in the very high-end on the TMA-2 as well.  But in general, it's not a stark difference for most situations and for listening to music it wasn't an issue for me.  But if you're using either set for recording or mixing, you do need to be aware of the frequency response for each in case you need to compensate for how you want the audio to sound vs. what you're hearing.  This is true of anything that isn't perfectly flat, though, and neither headphone is perfectly flat.  But I didn't come away listening to his headphones and feeling bad about my purchase.Right now, there is nothing else out there quite like these headphones and for that reason alone, I think these are worth a look for anyone looking for the flexibility and future expandability this pair offers.
title: My (current) favorite headphones
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2022

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: AIAIAI  top of the line for me. I used wired headphones for years and bought two high quality bluetooth headphones, but the delay made it impossible to use when recording live. So then went back to wired headphones. When searching for a fix for the delay problem I found someone who did a positive review of the TMA-2 Studio Wireless+. Ordered them and got them in three days expecting to return them. But no, they are great.  The headphones work perfect, the sound is good and now I get more work done comfortably. Have wires hanging down can pull things off the mount or desk. They come disassembled neatly package that takes 2 minutes to put together. As you assemble them you will understand the engineering quality. This company made these to be taken apart to replace anything that could get damaged in time so you can replace just that part. Yes, they have parts listed that you can buy. The build quality is of the highest standard and shows that it's about the customer and not just making a profit. Battery life is great. I will buy the next generation that they come out with. They say you can trade up, but I think I would keep the old set too.
title: When playing an instrument, you do not hear a Bluetooth delay.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: Bought two for band rehearsal - we have a rehearsal room with lots of gear and pedals and were always tripping over cables. The headphones sound great - very comfortable, no noticeable latency. Neat thing is they are modular so if by chance something breaks you can just buy that particular part and not have to get the entire headphone again. They also work as bluetooth phones - I find them more cozy than the Sony ones.
title: Bought Two for Band Rehearsal

text: This is game changer. I play guitar, and it's amazing that I can use this headphones without latency... it really helps when I have to put on and remove the guitar. Support is also great, my right speaker stopped working after 5 months (which is why the 4 starts) and they send me a coupon to get a replacement.
title: Game changer!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2023

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: These headphones work as advertised with the best non-noticeable latency I've ever experienced with studio level, wireless headphone. However, the W+ link can be glitchy at times (e.g., randomly disconnecting and reconnecting) and there is white noise. I personally don't mind the white noise, even for music production/monitoring. The sound is very balanced/flat, and comparable to the Audio-Technica ATH-M50X.As well, I had some manufacturing defect on some of the parts (e.g., screws not attached properly on headband and some left over plastic on the ear-cups).But my big issue with this product is not the product itself, but my experience with Amazon customer service. Two agents, on different days, promised that I'd received a partial refund and that could keep the headphones because of the manufacturing defects. However, a week after this solution was promised to me, an Amazon Leadership manager nullified the offer. And now I'm stuck with a great item with minor defects and a lack in trust with Amazon's promises.Anyways, bottom line, if you want/need studio wireless headphones for music production, monitoring and/or DJing look no further than the AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+.
title: Good product with minor defects and a bad experience with Amazon's service.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2022

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: These headphones deliver on the promise of low-latency wireless audio, but with some significant annoyances.The most annoying thing is they often randomly beep and makes the connection sound again, when they haven't actually lost connection. I can still hear my audio the whole time, with the volume reduced while this is happening. I contacted support about it and they said it will be fixed in a future firmware update. I'll update my review if/when that happens.I also hate that I have to hold down the power button for 5 seconds to turn the headphones on, and 3 seconds for the transmitter. It's just long enough to be annoying, and somehow the timing being different makes it feel more awkward.They're not my best-sounding headphones, nor my most comfortable headphones, and yes there is a noticeable background hiss when using the low latency wireless. But I'll still use them because low-latency wireless does make a big difference when you have too much gear in your studio to sit in one place all the time.
title: Annoying beeping sounds from firmware issue, long button holds
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2022

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: I Have gone through plenty of wireless headphones they all have major latency as far as signal frm synthesizer to turntables or even tablet or laptop I have yet to notice any major drops with the aiaiai in short a must have for producers /Dj’s /movies/synthesizers the best part of the headphones aside frm super low if none latency is the fact that the parts on the head set are all replaceable unlike countless manufacturers that make a product and if it breaks you have to buy a brand new pair thanks AiAiAi for creating something awesome and Reusable for the coming years I’m sure when I leave earth someone will continue to use and love em can’t say that with any other headsets
title: It’s everything they say it is an incredible wireless headset
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2022

product_name: AIAIAI TMA-2 Studio Wireless+ - World’s First Wireless Headphones for Music Creators
text: I bought these for a wireless guitar practice setup, as the headphones wires are annoying and one can't always be too loud in a house with other people around.I was very pleased to have found this model, and that it specifically targeted a low-latency use case. You see, usually wireless headphones are using bluetooth protocol and that often adds a very perceivable latency, making it impossible to use when playing an instrument.Unfortunately they didn't live up to the expectations. The latency in 2.4GHz mode is just fine, but everything else was not.Being positioned as "Studio" headphones targeted at "Music Creators" I expected them to produce a clear crisp sound. Not too loud, no bass boost, usually present on many consumer headphones, but plain clear, flat, even sound. Unfortunately this was not even remotely the case. While the bass does sound kind of OKish, everything above that is a muddy mess. I couldn't believe the difference between these and a pair of cheapo wired studio monitor headphones I have, for like 1/10 of the price of these. The cheapo ones deliver ten times the sound fidelity.The muddy sound persists in all modes of operation, be it 2.4GHz, Bluetooth or wired.I'm returning them.
title: Poor sound quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2023

product_name: ATYME 32-inch Class 60Hz 720p HD LED TV Flat Screen 1*USB 3* HDMI 1*VGA ARC Dual Channel 8W Speakers Monitor Television 320GM5HD
text: I know what you're thinking: then why the 4 starz if it's basic with crappy speakers. Right? Ok, well I needed a TV with no "smart" capabilities---I just needed a basic flat screen TV (for a bedroom) which was fresh on the shelf with a low price tag. This one hit that mark. The picture is not horrible but it's also not spectacular either (better than some, not as great as many others.) Besides the attached power cable (I prefer the power cable to have its own designated port in), and its annoyingly shrill & raspy sound, this TV hit all my marks! Actually what's more important to me about a flat TV is connectivity & this model offered far more than most @ 720p/60hz. 3 HDMIs (in)[1 of which is ARC---it can interfere with the performance of the other HDMIs *and is also not eARC* so this contributed to the loss of 1 star], PC(w/ a PC sound port), fiberoptic digital audio (out), and (the piece of resistance) a superb grandfinalè of a 3.5mm headphone AUX (out) port (this was just the best thing to find on the rear panel of the TV... ThE BeSt). Which brings me to my next point: speakers. Let's be honest, now; MoSt TVs have garbage for speakers (including many higher priced models). Well, with the ARC connectivity you can HDMI easily to a supporting soundbar or home theater system and with that fiberoptic or the AUX (outs), you can connect the TV sound easily even to older sound systems (just as I did with a Pioneer surround system from 2010). So the factory speakers were not a salepoint to me in the first place and barely affected the star rating at all. If you're looking for the perfect, all-in-1 TV; sound performance & detachable power cord had better not be a high priority for you with this model. However, if you need entertainment in another room from a smaller, better fitting screen size which happens to also support versatile connectivity; then this is the model for you to save some money on. And TV designers & retailers should take note here because many "smart" TVs are really a menace to deal with and some people know what they need without the "smart" functionalty; so maybe don't forget to stock some normal TVs for shoppers who are sick of how dumb many "smart" TVs actually are. Maybe design *ALL* TVs to have a smart *option* which can be used or not or even blocked from functioning so that the device will actually just work like a damned easy-to-use-basic TV. That's what I needed, that's what I found & bought so to me this TV is nothing but value -AnD- it's gravy to hook-up & use! But go get that great, big-ol' expensive picture & spectacular sound with its 1 (maybe 2) HDMI ports. My son is in his bedroom gaming & viewing on a pretty 32" with surround & it was well below the projected "son's room entertainment upgrade" budget which made a happy wifey. *AnD* he loves it because whatever sound the TV should be making is perfectly synced & blasting with surround-depth-of-sound, without blinding him & backlight-bleach-fading the paint off the walls while also potentially causing photo induced seizures & motion sickness. Like I said, nothing but value competetively priced.
title: A basic (unsmart) LEDTV with horrible speakers
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2023

text: The menu button on the remote control works wonders. It controls picture, audio, and more. For audio there are MODES: STANDARD is the default, and in fact a negative review of that mode is justified. BUT there is a MOVIE mode and a MUSIC mode. I was listening to a familiar piano concerto with familiar earphones while testing audio modes. When I got to MUSIC, bingo: sound suddenly as good as I expected. Picture controls for color, brightness, etc are as expected for HDMI DVDs and streaming, AND when using as a PC monitor via VGA, the menu also precisely positions the PC pixel array vertically and horizontally within the 32 inch panel. In other words, the remote control menu greatly improves an initial out-of-the-box experience.
